title: Could today's science fiction be future reality? - Quora

response.answer_text: Some thoughts on that. Science fiction as a thing is already real.No particular science fiction story is likely to ever “come true,” i.e., to become factual; it is, after all, fiction.Individual speculations in many science fiction stories have, over time, become “reality”; good examples include “waldoes” (robotic arms controlled by human hands in special gloves), from “Waldo” by Robert A. Heinlein, and flip phones, from Star Trek.Some individual speculations are already true when they are published. During World War II, Cleve Cartmill published a story in Astounding Stories called “Deadline”, which drew the attention of the FBI because it described a nuclear weapon too similar to the one being developed by the Manhattan Project.Some individual speculations are already false when they are published. In the early ‘60s, Larry Niven wrote a story called “The Coldest Place”, whose twist ending was that the incredibly cold place where it takes place is not the surface of Pluto but the dark side of Mercury. After it was sold, but before it was published, science discovered that Mercury is not (yet) tidally locked to the sun, and has no permanent “dark side”.There is no sixth item.Some individual speculations will never - well, let’s just say “are unlikely, given what we current know, ever to” - become realities: Faster-than-light travel, time travel to the past, anti-gravity, and similar ideas that make for good stories, but violate basic principles of what we currently think to be true about the Universe.Hope this is more help than confusion.

Lots of authors have predicted specific things that have then come about. Here’s a few off the top of my head: A man walked on the moon.Satellites are in geosynchronous orbits.Water beds.Flip phones and had-held computers.The rise of evangelicism in American politics.Wall-hung flat-screen big TVs.3D holograms.Nuclear warfare/atomic bombs.Establishing a new identity through computer manipulation.The First Lady having her won private astrologer.And some of the authors that made those ‘predictions’: Dozens of authors starting with Jules Verne.Arthur C. ClarkeRobert A. Heinlein.Star Trek.Heinlein again.Ray Bradbury, George Orwell.Star Wars.Cleve Cartmill.John Brunner.Yep, Heinlein again.Did they get all the details right? No, of course not. That is not the purpose of SF. The core requirement of SF is asking a question—’What if—?”, not making a prediction —’This will come to pass’. After having asked ‘what if’, the work may go on to giving a possible answer; but the main driver is the question. Many of these’predictions’ came about as a means of lending verisimilitude to an imagined world. That’s the role of the communicator and the note pads in Star Trek, for example. Some came about as a direct result of being familiar enough with the then-current scientific knowledge in a specific sphere to make informed extrapolations that turned out to be more or less accurate. I am thinking specifically of Cartmill’s Deadline, which got him investigated by the FBI when Astounding published it in 1944, because it predicted atomic bombs, and the science was very accurate, within the constraints of the story. The Manhattan Project was in full swing at the time, and the story scared government that the secret had leaked. It hadn’t; knowing the non-classified science was sufficient for anyone that truly KNEW to science to predict, rather accurately, the atomic bomb. Any psychic/astrologer will be accurate a certain small percentage of the time if that person makes enough predictions. So too will science fiction hit the nail on the head sometimes if enough of it is written.

In years past, many of the stories in science fiction included descriptions of possible future technologies - and their impact on society - which turned out to be rather prophetic. Now, not so much, as all the really viable ideas have been explored and exploited. It seems unlikely that a science fiction author will imagine a technology that is not obvious that is also viable. Some of the concepts that can never be viable are used again and again, like time travel, teleportation, dimensions as realms (in physics, dimensions are humble metrics, not realms at all), faster than light travel, and so on. It seems that in the minds of many, the past predictions that turned out to be prophetic means that all and every fantasy will become reality, just you wait and see. For certain ideas, you’ll be waiting a long time if you wait until they become real.

Absolutely. The science fiction of the 1960s is fast becoming science fact. Carl Sagan and Arthur C Clarke have shown us the future with their books and films. Most recently in the 2010s we have seen the introduction of (mostly) science fact films. However, we must be careful not to take this too far. My favourite film of that 1960s era was 2001: A Space Odyssey. The spaceship technology was good but we must treat the Black Hole entry with scepticism. Much the same could be said about the film Interstellar. Also, I would not get too excited about the 'warp' speed travel found within Star Trek. Some things are just too fantastical!

Yes. In part.  Already several sci fi ideas have become reality. For example the atomic bomb  which was talked about in the H.G. Well's novel "The World Set Free"   What about the communicator that the Star Fleet folk used.  Those have become our cell phones.   Computers were grist for sci fi stories long before they ended up on our desks or in our pockets.  And the laser is a clunky version of Buck Roger's ray gun.  And how about rocket ships that carry men to other planets.  It happened in 1969.  Hooda thunk it.

Loosely speaking, yes. There are works of science fiction that have anticipated some future developments in general terms. Armoured self-propelled vehicles were anticipated in the 1890s along with a submarine with a cruising range that spanned the globe. Robert A. Heinlein predicted both mobile phones and what an inconvenience they could be in the 50s. Mind you, there are always details that are inaccurate if you compare fiction to reality with rigor. Real submarines don’t and can’t attack by pulling a kamikaze on surface ships. Real tanks are a tenth of the size of the leviathans in the stories.

It has often happened in the past, so yes of course. Now, we need to distinguish fantasy and soft SF from hard SF. Hard SF is based on known science and technology, as well as extrapolations from those considered plausible by recognized experts. The other two are looser, and may be impossible. Our forthcoming SF TV series will be written so as to assure that it’s plausible—and that the world it depicts is desirable.

In the great majority of cases, no. The track record of science fiction authors as prophets is notably poor. Even when they have predicted a device or capability that eventually came into existence in a general sense, they have missed a lot of important details. Science fiction is a wonderful means of inspiring efforts to advance technology, but the end result doesn't match the dream.

It can. Sort of. Science fiction sometimes predicts things that end up happening (a typical example is Star Trek TNG predicting the tablet or the original series predicting the cellphone, sort off). It is also entirely possible but hard to prove conclusively for sure that science fiction writing has an inspirational impact on what scientists choose to spend their time trying to realise.

Its already become reality.   We already did those. Humanity goes space, Moon and deepest places on oceans.  We have already cell phones which more capable than Star Trek communicator. We have drones which can controled other side of Earth and make attack. We can talk each other face to face thanks to İnternet over great distances.
Rarely.  Look back at SF of the 1940s, 50s, 60s etc.  They got some things right. But a lot wrong.

Of course, in the general sense. Jules Verne published From the Earth to the Moon in 1865 (the characters only circumnavigate the moon and do not land). A century later, it was happening for real, and numerous works of fiction had depicted moon expeditions in the meantime. Jules Verne even had his heroes being launched into space from Florida. Sure enough, that is where Apollo 11 took off from.
